qa_pairs.question: What is the biggest disparity affecting students according to Shayla Putnam?
qa_pairs.answer: Income really truly is the biggest disparity because with income comes out of privilege like living in the mission versus living in Sunset is quite different.
qa_pairs.source_text: I would say that income really truly is the biggest disparity uh because with income comes out of privilege like living in the mission versus living in Sunset is quite different.

qa_pairs.question: How does Shayla Putnam describe the differences between living in the Mission and the Sunset?
qa_pairs.answer: Living in the Mission is more lively with more transportation, noise, and people out late, while the Sunset is quieter with less access to transportation and restaurants but has a strong community feel.
qa_pairs.source_text: I live in the sunset and Ive lived in the mission and I would say those are the two I can speak on the most um I really love the mission um because of all the storefronts underneath so you can within like a couple block radius you can really just like live its very walkable... its a lot more quiet out here uh people really care about the neighborhood theres a lot of community even though its not like nurses saying hi to your neighbor every day but we do look out for each other.

qa_pairs.question: What transportation issues does Shayla Putnam highlight in the Sunset?
qa_pairs.answer: There is a lack of transportation options like BART, and buses are overcrowded during school start and end times, making it difficult for students to commute.
qa_pairs.source_text: I mean it would be a miracle to get Bart or anything out on this side but I think thats long gone... Ill even have students wait an hour after school just hanging out in my room just because they like I really dont want to deal with the next three buses that are going to be just packed.

qa_pairs.question: What does Shayla Putnam wish for in terms of access to arts and culture in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: She wishes for more access to arts or music, more publicized events, and possibly reduced prices for residents to access museums and creative outlets.
qa_pairs.source_text: I would like to see more of that happen um I know other cities uh I think when I visited um St Louis recently all their art museums are free so anyone can go in anyone can access those I wish there was a little bit more access to arts or like music um more publicized I think we rely on the internet a lot but also Flyers do a lot too.

qa_pairs.question: How does Shayla Putnam view the role of teachers and community in supporting students after school?
qa_pairs.answer: Teachers often volunteer to provide a safe space for students after school, as there are not many compensated opportunities for such activities.
qa_pairs.source_text: There are a lot of after school programs the school does provide but a lot of that is a volunteer work by teachers or like clubs or Sports theres not a lot of opportunities for teachers to like provide their space for students or provide an activity where it is compensated.

qa_pairs.question: What aspect of San Francisco does Shayla Putnam enjoy sharing with visitors?
qa_pairs.answer: She enjoys showing visitors the mom and pop shops, the walkability, and the multicultural aspect of the city.
qa_pairs.source_text: My favorite thing about San Francisco is the mom and pop shops... anytime I have people visit like thats the part of San Francisco I show them I show them that you can walk to this store get a coffee go to the next one get a nice fresh pastry or go down the road and get a Mediterranean lunch.

qa_pairs.question: What are Shayla Putnam's hopes for housing in San Francisco?
qa_pairs.answer: She hopes that housing will become more accessible and affordable for the actual citizens of the city, not just the wealthy.
qa_pairs.source_text: I do have hopes that housing just will become more accessible um I dont know what person looks at a 1.5 million dollar I was like I got that thats nothing I can pay for that um so I would I would like to see like just housing costs go down and just be more mindful of the actual citizens of the city and not the most wealthy that make it here and can afford those prices.
